title: 103_hr3943
content: The Act is titled the "Senior Citizens Housing Safety Act" and includes a limitation on occupancy in public housing designated for elderly families. The United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to include a limitation on occupancy in projects designated for elderly families. The United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to include restrictions on occupancy in projects designated for elderly and disabled families, prohibiting individuals with drug or alcohol-related disabilities or behaviors that may interfere with the safety and peaceful enjoyment of other tenants from residing in such units. The United States Housing Act of 1937 now includes restrictions on occupancy in projects designated for elderly and disabled families, requiring a signed statement from non-elderly occupants that they do not have a history of drug or alcohol use that could disrupt the safety and peaceful enjoyment of other tenants. SEC. 3 amends Section 6(l) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 to include provisions for termination of tenancy in case of violation of certain sections. SEC. 4 addresses the provision of Section 8 assistance to move nonelderly tenants with drug or alcohol use problems from public housing designated for elderly families. Section 7(c) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to limit evictions of tenants in public housing projects, except for nonelderly tenants with drug or alcohol issues in housing designated for elderly families. The United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to limit evictions of elderly and disabled families in public housing projects, with a preference for Section 8 assistance provided on behalf of the tenant. The United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to limit evictions of elderly and disabled families in public housing projects by requiring eviction under certain circumstances if assistance is provided on behalf of the family.
